author: tinyraccoon
body:
Generally, I try to diversify not only in terms of sectors but also in terms of style (e.g. value vs. growth) and exposure (e.g. cyclical vs. secular growth, foreign exposed vs. domestic).  At any given time, certain stocks tend to do well while others not as well, so by diversifying exposures, it is less frequent that the entire portfolio will go down.  

For example, due to the coronavirus and global fears, secular growth and/or more domestic stocks like MSFT, CRM, GD are doing better nowadays.  However, if the coronavirus fears subside, cyclical and more globally exposed stocks like CAT, CVX, SBUX might start coming back and the current leaders might take a breather.

author: PracticalArtist4
body:
> But Im starting to wonder if hard work analysis pays off.

Why? Because somehow doing a 40 page paper researching every single line item on an obscure chemicals company is supposed to entitle you to to incredible returns? 

Hard work does not equate to superior returns. Finding amazing companies that are growing their earnings power equates to superior returns. 

It blows my mind every time I see a value investor lamenting how "easy" it has been for tech investors to make money. Yes buying and holding amazon or apple or salesforce has been an amazing strategy for the last 10 years and its been "easy" vs scouring through the filings and identifying a cigar butt.. no doubt. But the genius has been in identifying that the Amazons, Apple's, Salesforce's of the world have FAR superior business models compared to brick and mortar traditional businesses. 

TL;DR Hard work is important, but it doesn't guarantee returns. Finding great companies and holding on to them guarantees returns.

author: Zer033x
body:
NVDA is on fire lately. Great earnings and lots of analyst upgrades.

TTD will likely beat earnings next week, might make a run to mid 320s before earnings.

PTON is near bottomed out, so probably only up from here til next earnings.

ROKU is pretty low despite a good beat on earnings and will likely rebound to high 130s low 140s in a week or two.

BA is auto buy on calls in the 325-330 range or lower, so much bad news could only push it that low.

Despite TSLA runup it's still a valid play on dips to 800s or lower, a lot of demand still.

MSFT is awaiting Jedi contract decision so is likely range bound between 182-187 until then.

XOP and other fuel/oil type stocks are at lows and consolidating, could be good medium/long term to play a bounce.

Once Coronavirus news dies down AAPL will be in 340s or higher due to a great earnings release that never really got realized in stock price.

WYNN is a valid Coronavirus rebound play.

AMD is a very strong stock right now. It's run up a lot lately but has strong support in mid 50s.

SPCE is a meme stock but can make you rich or wipe you out. Keep bets small and potentially triple your money or more. Strangle could even work with how much it moves.

Cloud stocks and software are actually pretty resilient right now and if Coronavirus news spreads could be considered safe haven. Things like CRM TWLO OKTA MSFT NOW ADBE MDB.

author: jasonlurk
body:
High growth tech names like SHOP, AYX, ZM, DDOG just to pick a few all have high multiples. But names like these have historically had higher multiples than the rest of the market. The question for me is whether these names deserve to have extreme multiples relative to companies that look just like them historically. 

The answer for me is no. These companies trade at 3-5x higher multiples than companies who were consistently growing  +40% annually. I track software names and have been doing so for personal and professional reasons for 20 years. A high growth name like SHOP could consistently get a 8-12x trailing revenue multiple. Today its 30-40x. 

There is no justification for the multiples we are seeing today. You cannot model out a scenario where these companies grow into their multiples and feel good about betting on that business case. I say this because there are only a handful of precedents who have managed to grow at a high rate and generate cash flow over long (5-7years or more) periods of time. 

You cant hold out hope that a big strategic will take them out at these levels because the price point is too dilutive. Plus there is practically been no strategic M&A for these faster growers in the last year or so. I think the best case you find is Salesforce acquiring Tableau. And DATA in that situation had slowed but CRM didn’t pay 30-40x revenue for it either. Another one could be IBM buying Red Hat but then again IBM paid alot for the business but no where near 25x revenue. 

SHOP and others are trading at outrageous multiples but beware these are not sustainable and they leave no room for error.

author: Sir-Lt-Cpt-Obvious
body: $160 calls are a guarantee that you can buy the stock for $160 even if they shot up to $1,000 over night, which is why options can be so valuable. However, they have to be above the strike... in this case  $160.  Right now your calls are basically worthless because it's very very unlikely IBM will hit $160 tomorrow, and if it does, your $160 call would still be worthless, unless the stock  surpassed $160. This is why a short expiration on options can be so risky.

I know what you are getting at.  Just the generalized nature of your post begs to have it picked apart.  Apple down a few points is just day to day movement.  That’s not cut a cut bait example;e by any means.  

But look at Warren Buffet for example when he sunk billions into IBM stock.  He had over 10 billion worth at an average price of 170.  It was a declining stock for the majority of the time he held it ranging from 150-110 / share.  He eventually dumped it at a loss so he could put that money to better use elsewhere. author: steve_park
body: Let's assume you have 10 155 IBM calls expiring 2/7. That would represent 1,000 shares. You'd need 150K in your account or your broker would automatically close these out because they would be exercised into equity. You are in the 160 so your position will expire worthless since IBM is at 156.76. Let's do a hypothetical and assume IBM gets upgraded tomorrow and share surge to 161 past the 160 strike putting you in the money. Your broker would automatically close you out at 3:45 eastern whatever the price is if you didn't have enough to cover the position.  This is useful to know because many traders trade in the money options to avoid premium decay. Avoid deep OTM options if you are new to options world. Quickest way to blow up your account.

author: PapaCharlie9
body:
Where is your list of disadvantages?

My question, every time this topic comes up, is if we accept for the sake of argument that this time it's different, what exactly is different? What has so fundamentally changed that the long-term historic trends are now dead as dinosaurs?

While all of those things you listed are advantages, they aren't advantages that weren't available to the large caps of the previous century. There was a time when IBM, T, XOM, GE, GM, JNJ, etc., seemed unstoppable large caps that could never be toppled from their top 10 positions, and yet they eventually were. 

MSFT and AAPL started out small to mid caps. Of course, not every small cap is going to turn into an MSFT or AAPL, or even 1 out of a 1000, but if the argument is that we should only buy stocks once they are large and established, isn't that also saying wait until they are more expensive?

author: ribnag
body:
Because the market goes down, and the market goes up, but those sweet sweet dividends flow either way.

If it takes the market a decade to recover from the current artificially-maintained bull, are you going to sit on cash losing 2% per year to inflation the whole time, or are you going to at least enjoy 3% growth year over year regardless of actual stock prices?

And in fact, dividend yield usually goes **up** in a bear market, because the DOW is largely meaningless to the day-to-day spending of the Joe Average.  If IBM is issuing $6/year in dividends, at $150/share, that's 4%; at $100/share, that's 6%.

author: IAMV100
body:
It sounds like you are perhaps uninformed, but not dumb. Dumb people are those that have the information and opportunities but still choose to ignore them. Uninformed people just don't know any better, and it sounds like you had the kind of environment that didnt foster financial learning or stability. Reaching out and trying to better your future sounds pretty smart to me.

On average the S&P500 increases about 8-10% annually. Look up SPY and VOO ETFs, which track the S&P500 (500 biggest companies on the US stock market). People are usually better off buying and holding those than picking individual stocks. At that rate of return, you might expect between 59-75k if you invest $100/month for 20 years due to compound interest.

Also, 53 isnt too late for you! You have another 20-30 years left statistically, possibly more with medical advancements. A lot of great people didn't make it big until their 50s. IBM and Home Depot were started by a 61 and 50 year old, you've still got opportunity left! Good luck!

author: MaliciousLegroomMelo
body:
While I would agree with the general thesis that Intel has lost a few notches of their technical superiority, do you think that necessarily translates into stock price?  Such tectonic shifts - if real - can take a very long time.  

There used to be a saying "nobody ever got fired for picking IBM". It took decades for that rule to fade.  The same is true of Intel.  AMD may indeed be crushing it on tech, and winning customers one at a time.  But it will take a long time for Intel to lose their dominance, even if it's warranted.  

Keep in mind the just had a blowout quarter.  Companies pay them $73 billion a year for what is essentially melted sand.  

Perhaps their blowout is due to low analyst expectations.  But that's a condition that can take a quarter or two to rectify as the analysts gradually tweak their recommendations and targets to levels where Intel will struggle or miss.  That means they could beat again next quarter.  

They now have a permanent CEO who is a numbers guy, who reported is working for peanut salary with a strong incentive to crank those numbers.

Your diagnosis is they've lost their way in product architecture and design and innovation. I won't argue as I wouldn't know and your case sounds plausible.  If so, then they probably have the wrong CEO since he doesn't sound like he'd be the inspiring voice to revive the product innovation.

I sense the author is a die hard AMD fan, which is fine.  But AMD having a cooler product doesn't necessarily put Intel out of business.  Coke and Pepsi continue to punch the clock and fight each other.  And AMD's multiple is so out of whack that they probably need to crank up earnings by cranking up sales but any moves they make on price or competitiveness won't be as a monopoly; they'll be done with Intel fighting them for every inch.

To me that means even if your theory of AMD taking the crown from Intel is happening, it will be a slow moving coup.

author: david_chi
body:
I know what you are getting at.  Just the generalized nature of your post begs to have it picked apart.  Apple down a few points is just day to day movement.  That’s not cut a cut bait example;e by any means.  

But look at Warren Buffet for example when he sunk billions into IBM stock.  He had over 10 billion worth at an average price of 170.  It was a declining stock for the majority of the time he held it ranging from 150-110 / share.  He eventually dumped it at a loss so he could put that money to better use elsewhere.  He loaded up on Apple and those shares are now worth almost 2x what he paid.  Had he stuck with IBM stock waiting for a recovery that never happened he would still be very much in the red today.

Where is your list of disadvantages?

My question, every time this topic comes up, is if we accept for the sake of argument that this time it's different, what exactly is different? What has so fundamentally changed that the long-term historic trends are now dead as dinosaurs?

While all of those things you listed are advantages, they aren't advantages that weren't available to the large caps of the previous century. There was a time when IBM, T, XOM, GE, GM, JNJ, etc., seemed unstoppable large caps that could never be toppled from their top 10 positions, and yet they eventually were. 

MSFT and AAPL started out small to mid caps. Of course, not every small cap is going to turn into an MSFT or AAPL, or even 1 out of a 1000, but if the argument is that we should only buy stocks once they are large and established, isn't that also saying wait until they are more expensive?

author: ribnag
body:
Because the market goes down, and the market goes up, but those sweet sweet dividends flow either way.

If it takes the market a decade to recover from the current artificially-maintained bull, are you going to sit on cash losing 2% per year to inflation the whole time, or are you going to at least enjoy 3% growth year over year regardless of actual stock prices?

And in fact, dividend yield usually goes **up** in a bear market, because the DOW is largely meaningless to the day-to-day spending of the Joe Average.  If IBM is issuing $6/year in dividends, at $150/share, that's 4%; at $100/share, that's 6%.

author: IAMV100
body:
It sounds like you are perhaps uninformed, but not dumb. Dumb people are those that have the information and opportunities but still choose to ignore them. Uninformed people just don't know any better, and it sounds like you had the kind of environment that didnt foster financial learning or stability. Reaching out and trying to better your future sounds pretty smart to me.

On average the S&P500 increases about 8-10% annually. Look up SPY and VOO ETFs, which track the S&P500 (500 biggest companies on the US stock market). People are usually better off buying and holding those than picking individual stocks. At that rate of return, you might expect between 59-75k if you invest $100/month for 20 years due to compound interest.

Also, 53 isnt too late for you! You have another 20-30 years left statistically, possibly more with medical advancements. A lot of great people didn't make it big until their 50s. IBM and Home Depot were started by a 61 and 50 year old, you've still got opportunity left! Good luck!

author: MaliciousLegroomMelo
body:
While I would agree with the general thesis that Intel has lost a few notches of their technical superiority, do you think that necessarily translates into stock price?  Such tectonic shifts - if real - can take a very long time.  

There used to be a saying "nobody ever got fired for picking IBM". It took decades for that rule to fade.  The same is true of Intel.  AMD may indeed be crushing it on tech, and winning customers one at a time.  But it will take a long time for Intel to lose their dominance, even if it's warranted.  

Keep in mind the just had a blowout quarter.  Companies pay them $73 billion a year for what is essentially melted sand.  

Perhaps their blowout is due to low analyst expectations.  But that's a condition that can take a quarter or two to rectify as the analysts gradually tweak their recommendations and targets to levels where Intel will struggle or miss.  That means they could beat again next quarter.  

They now have a permanent CEO who is a numbers guy, who reported is working for peanut salary with a strong incentive to crank those numbers.

Your diagnosis is they've lost their way in product architecture and design and innovation. I won't argue as I wouldn't know and your case sounds plausible.  If so, then they probably have the wrong CEO since he doesn't sound like he'd be the inspiring voice to revive the product innovation.

I sense the author is a die hard AMD fan, which is fine.  But AMD having a cooler product doesn't necessarily put Intel out of business.  Coke and Pepsi continue to punch the clock and fight each other.  And AMD's multiple is so out of whack that they probably need to crank up earnings by cranking up sales but any moves they make on price or competitiveness won't be as a monopoly; they'll be done with Intel fighting them for every inch.

To me that means even if your theory of AMD taking the crown from Intel is happening, it will be a slow moving coup.

author: Captain-i0
body:
> SaaS is up like a rocket today. Appian, Okta, Splunk, Salesforce.. it's weird

They have workforces than can easily work from home. They are recurring contract based. The majority of their contracts are with large corporations that aren't going to stop using their service during a recession.  Many companies have much of their infrastructure built through these platforms. They aren't going to just kill them, unless they are completely closing up shop for good. 

They won't see as many new investments during a recession, but they aren't going to lose much in the way of customers, and some companies may use this time to spend on internal projects. I was surprised they ever were taking much of a hit in this crash to begin with. If you can get them cheap, I would.

The consensus seems to be that the CDC made some bad decisions early on, including developing their own ineffectual [Coronavirus test](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/03/01/health-officials-probe-coronavirus-cdc-118523). I am sure that we will see a considerable uptick in cases within the next two weeks across North America. If the Fed lowers interest rates this week, it will be a critical error to do so simply to quell a bearish market.

I think that while investors cry at the Fed and markets rise in the early hours of the 2nd, buy month-long puts in manufacturing and tourism sectors. This bull market is not going down without a fight.

So...  
Put - $LVS, 3/20, $57.5

author: trilogee
body:
* They have the higest margins of any pure play retailer in the country (excluding legacy businesses). Sequential revenue increases since company's inception.
* They have a proprietary CRM and analytics platform in hifyre that allows them to capture actionable insights on consumer spending and preferences. 
* They have the country's largest private database of retail customers through Spark Perks (over 50k members as of last q).
* With the exception of the OCS they easily have the retail industry's most accessible and optimized e-commerce platform.
* They have one of a few wholesale operations in SK which will enable them to vie for any future private wholesale decisions ON makes.  
* They have the expertise to operate with compliance, in a highly regulated market (former mettrum/emblem execs). 
* They have the backing and support of $60B retail behemoth Alimentation Couche Tard (think about all the benefits this offers in terms of real estate, operational efficiencies, network etc.) 
* They are partnered with CBRE and have access to prime real estate (<-- huge). 
* They are better capitalized than ANY other retailer in the country and even more so than most LPs.
* They have an immediately recognizable brand with search interest that far outweighs their competition (check google trends).
* CEO already forcasted profitability for Q2 2020.

No question that competition is going to be stiff - many retailers will fail; there's also room for many to succeed. Those who do will demonstrate discipline in cost control, will leverage data to order and stock products that sell, and will work with LPs to produce products that they know customers will want.

Edit: Also to be clear, there are only about 190 ROLs issued thus far. 800 applications total. 190 or less RSAs have been submitted depending on who was ready at midnight yesterday.

author: tehnoodles
body:
At a very small scale software like DNAC or DCNM works ok. Try to scale this to 10,000's of nodes, and it starts to fall apart. I have seen this multiple different times, and this was using recommended compute hardware given to us by cisco to try and make it work.

The automation software crumbles when you reach scales the require automation, which completely defeats the purpose.

I also didn't say their hardware has issues. Aside from the usual bug schedule (which cisco is no better/worse than anyone else) their hardware is rocksolid, it really comes down to the software for the API on the devices, or the software of tools to manage it.

Cisco is only a leader in the market when you look at the entire breadth of their portfolio because: No one else is spread as thin. Only Juniper comes close and IMO and while i like SRX, it's not a while lot better than Firepower. Their ability to automate though? Leaps and bounds above cisco, and their hardware platform is arguable just as mature as any that cisco has on the market.

author: tendieshitter
body:
First off, visit [optionsprofitcalculator.com](https://optionsprofitcalculator.com) to get an idea what you would make with the move of an option. It's usually difficult to calculate given all the variables, but this site should help.

" say I expect the stock to hit $35.50 at some point that day and I would  sell it, I would want to buy a put option because I expect the stock to  go down on Monday. This protects me and provides me with the opportunity  to sell my 100 shares at $36.62 still, when the current price is  $35.50. Correct? "

No. If you expect a red Monday and you already own 100 shares of Cisco you plan to sell, you are already dealing with a loss. Furthermore, if you expect the price to go down further you would be good to buy a put contract on Cisco. 

If you want to hang on to your shares of Cisco because you expect them to go up, but want "insurance" against that, you could also buy a put contract in case the price goes down.

author: SUPER_swan
body:
The ESPP program you have is a great money maker for you.


Look at the last 10 years of the stock, not the last 6 months. Cisco has slowly gone up.


Lets say your required holding period is 1 year. That means if you hold the stock for 1 year and the stock doesn’t budge in price. If you sell you gain the 15% in the discount plus 4% from the dividend you gained as well. Historically, the stock has gone up as well, which also increase your gains.

So, continue to buy your company stock.


Now there is some people I bet at your work, just like mine, that have bought their company stock for 20+ years and never sold. Doing this increasing your exposure to that one company. If the company tanks, your stock will be worth a lot less and you could be out of a job.


However, if you go with selling right after your lock out period it’s a great way to use that discount to generate more money for you. 


Relax investing is a marathon not a sprint.

author: espresso_inflective
body:
>I'm sorry, but people stuck at home won't be buying fewer Apple products to entertain themselves with, even if there is a delay in receiving the product from Apple, and Cisco won't stop building the internet that more people will use when they quarantined at home, and people won't go on Twitter less when they stuck at home, or buy less bandaids from JNJ, or stop buying laundry detergent from PG.

All of these are examples of demand shock, which I think most people agree is not the issue here. The issue is a supply shock: Apple is going to produce less, Cisco is going to have trouble obtaining their parts, Twitter's advertisers are going to experience similar shocks and buy fewer advertisements, and PG is going to have trouble sourcing the inputs for its laundry detergent.

author: Bartlet4America94
body:
Copying my comment regarding RH suits:

If you file in court, they’ll move to dismiss, since the “proper” venue is via a FINRA arbitration. 

A bunch of these popping up will cause headaches, but it’ll probably be a copy-paste type motion to dismiss, so it won’t cost them that much $. Lack of PJ, improper venue, even SJ since it’s all federal securities (though many states have their own securities regulatory bodies).

Now, there are jurx that don’t follow mandatory arbitration (LA, NC) so technically those RH users in these states could file and not necessarily get bumped out on the MtD phase. However, since this is mainly federal stuff, I still think most courts will defer to FINRA.

The main strategy would be to file in court and then immediately leverage settlement before the judge rules on dismissal. Settlement for each individual case would be low and so would be the bargaining power of the potential plaintiff. You’d want to consolidate all actions into a class. The problem with this is it takes time and then you’ll have fights over class cert. that can move the settlement needle back and forth.

author: Salty_Cornflakes
body:
To all those crying about the death of WSB, here is a mod's response:

 

* We're working on it. We've made a few adjustments already that have helped immensely. I'd wager that 4/5 of the posts that you're complaining about don't even see the light of day. Which should impress and terrify you.
* It's difficult trying to strike a balance. The public attention has brought a lot of legitimate traders here who just want to share their experience, real DD, technical analysis, etc and we want to encourage that. They obviously make new accounts and we want them to contribute immediately.
* We're tweaking things everyday in response to rapidly changing growth and news that swings the entire sub in a matter of hours (like our pumping problem last week). This weeked now everyone is talking about their local Costco, committing bioterroism, and killing the pope. Also, please calm the fuck down with killing the pope, guys. It's borderline enciting violence, I've temp banned a few people who take it wayyyy too far.
* Our sexuality aside, we're volunteers from around the world. Our hours and availability differ, so there are mod lulls where a lot of one liner shitposts get through. We do our best, but we really focus on providing the best experience we can for you guys during trading hours when the engagement here is through the roof.
* As far as you or others wanting to volunteer, you guys actually do a pretty good job en mass with downvoting and reporting bullshit. Keep it up. We appreciate that.

That's all I got at the moment. Hope it gives you some kind of something.

author: Sikeitsryan
body:
since no ones helped you out

options are contracts entered into by you and someone else (a counter party). There's 2 types of options, puts and calls. If you look at OP's picture you'll see that one of his "trades" is for SQQQ $29 CALL 3/20.

So he wants to buy a call. Now, like I said this call is a contract between OP and someone else. This contract states that at anytime between the day that OP purchases the call contract and the expiration date of the contract, stated as 3/20/2020. OP has the 'option' or choice to buy 100 shares of the etf SQQQ from the counter party of the contract for $29 regardless of what the actual price of the ETF is.

&#x200B;

So theoretically, if on 3/15 SQQQ is trading at $50 a share, OP can exercise his option and buy those 100 shares for $29 dollars from the counter party and sell those shares immediately in the open market for $50. 

&#x200B;

The downside is that OP has to pay the counter party a 'premium' in order to have this option. Right now the premium has a bid/ask of $2.65 x 2.95. So if OP wants to buy the call he has to pay $2.95 x 100 (per share, remember the call gives op the right to buy 100 shares from the counter party). Now, you may be asking, why is the spread so wide? Wouldn't OP immediately lose $30 or 10% on his trade? Is OP gambling with probably zero actual insight on investing? I'll let you figure those out on your own.
